title.narrative: Strengthening partner staff capacities through encyclical “Laudato Si" and climate change courses

description.narrative:
In this region the problem of climate change is still relevant for rural communities, especially those located in the dry corridor.
According to the GermanWatch Climate Change Index, Central American countries are more affected by extreme climatic events such as earthquakes, droughts, floods. landslides, and eruptions. The frequency of natural disaster occurrences will increase as a result of climate change. The region will be hit increasingly harder over the next 50 years if we don’t take action to mitigate and adapt (ECLA, 2009). Those poor rural communities are trapped in a cycle of poverty and lack of access to good nutritious food, incomes and water.
This Project is part of the Livelihoods Programme implemented in Central American countries (El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, and Nicaragua). This programme has as its objective to contribute to the improvement of the conditions/quality of life of the men and women of the poorest and most excluded communities, strengthen their livelihoods, risk management and resilience capacities in the face of climate change.
The project aim is strengthening capacity of technician teams to improve their programming design, practices and knowledge to integrate a new integrated approach to development work. CAFOD has been working in the past supporting local partners to build adaptation and mitigation strategies through improving their capacities and the resilience of communities by linking them together with other actors to address climate change. Now Cafod is exploring work through academic courses, as another way to continue to support with new tools and methods the work in the region
The academic course will be accredited by the Universidad Centroamericana (UCA), and will consist in 100 hrs of classroom time, divided into 7 modules. Each module will have 3 weekend sessions for a total of 21 weekend sessions with 5 hours each session.
